questions.question_text: Six months after a new version of an OS was released to the market, end users began to lose access to application updates. Which of the following was MOST likely the reason for this issue?

discussion.content: Another poorly worded question.

Guys please, it doesn't matter if the version is six months old... Just read the 'and users began to lose access to application updates' . I swear you guys are literally making it soooooooooo difficult for yourself.

Its a poorly worded question but to those who stayed and studied long enough for this EXAM, knows that they are hinting on End-of-life. (Probably not a in-real-life situation answer but hey welcome to the world of COMPTIA)
Onlt 6 month application was released on the market, guys this question is not yet complte bcs how can it be end of life when it was realesed only 6 month. Im confussed.com
End of life after only 6 months?

comments.content: It doesn't say that the computers losing access have been updated. It is likely they are still on the older version which is being phased out. But still 6 months is not long for everyone to update.

questions.question_text: A technician is deploying a PXE installation of a new OS onto a small group of company workstations. Which of the following should the technician monitor during the installation?

discussion.content:
The technician will have configured, tested and fixed the image on an identical test machine before deployment. The hosts will also have been prepared for PXE installation so it is unlikely that they will face any issues.
On the other hand, PXE is deployed over a network which creates a lot of additional traffic and stress. This could cause various network issues related to load and installation servers could become unresponsive if too many requests are performed at once.
C Because too many machines on a PXE can cause a freeze or failure.
why not A ?

comments.content:
"a new OS onto a small group of company workstations"
why not go straight to workstations instead to network?

discussion.content: Answer is definitely A

comments.content: Correct, if they asked for storing it, then you could say an antistatic bag. (I'm guilty as hell with this, I store mine in a closet on a shelf, over carpet which I walk in socks on........Welcome to Static Park)
I think D. ESD strap is correct. Keyword is during. This would prevent electrostatic discharge damaging the device while replacing it.
No. The bags are for storage. The question is about the replacement process itself.

questions.question_text: A desktop technician needs to replace a laptop's SSD. Which of the following must the technician use to prevent damage to the SSD during the replacement?

An office building lost power, and the generator started up. Users on several floors have reported their machines will not start, even though the generator is running. A technician works to divert power from other floors until all users are able to work. Which of the following is the BEST solution for the technician to recommend?

discussion.content: Gentlemen, some of you seem to be ignoring the Objective 4.7 - using proper communication techniques and professionalism. Or is this how you plan to communicate with your colleagues and clients?
Users on (several floors) have reported their machines will not start

D is correct, I am assuming that this is a poorly designed generator back up system. if generator is not producing enough power then it won't power all the floors, remember that each floor has bigger loads than just computers (Air conditioning, Coffee machines etc) ...

After a lot of consideration i think it should actually be A. I did think D initially, but as others have said if the power can be diverted there must be enough being produced by the generator to power the whole building.
The question states "users on several floors have reported their machines will not start.", it doesn't say whether the entire floor is without power or just odd users dotted about but let's look at the implications.

Odd users - random computers here and there cannot start. Could be lack of current overall, could be blown fuses from the generator kicking in tbh or could be a few other things. Either way harder to diagnose and unlikely to be fixed by diverting more power.

Entire floor - This would imply something has happened to the power coming to this floor, could be and RCD on the generator blew, could be a rat chewed the cable (remember this is backup cabling so the connections to the mains havent been used for a while). This WOULD be fixed by diverting power from another floor because you've bypassed the damaged part of the circuit. In this event adding redundancy to the cabling would actually have helped, if there was a redundant ;ink to the mains then there would still have been power going to those floors.
D is correct. If you have to redirect power between floors then the generator does not have enough capacity to power the whole building in an emergency.

If I am to make solutions for recommendations like the scenario asks. I would go with B, have more battery back ups for the users so when the power trips and turns off. the back ups will keep the systems going until the generator kicks in. you wont have lose in connection in theory.

comments.content: It is D. Redundancy won't help if there is not enough power for everyone. Diverting power means decreasing power output to one area, increasing to another area

discussion.content: After considering a little bit longer - D could be right. Because, it is writtent that "he is working to diverge energy from other floors" - so he did not manage it yet probably? that is why he should probably recomend better generator first....?

comments.content: My thinking exactly if it works when he has fixed it than generator is good enough,

I think the key is that it doesn't say "distribute" it says "divert." This implies that the tech is taking power from another part of the building to power the machines. This also implies that the generator is not supplying enough power to the entire building.

It's diverting it, meaning taking away. If the generator was enough for the entire building, then you would not have to divert power. A battery backup would last whatever small amount of time they're allotted by manufacturer and w/e equipment is connected. Whomever installed the generator didn't account for growth in the facility or did so for w/e was asked of it at the time of construction.

discussion.content: How can this be right? The Question suggest that the technician can distribute power from other floors.. so the generator must have enough power.. more redundancy on the other hand would help I guess?

choices.B: Purchase more battery backups for individual users
choices.D: Increase the capacity of the backup generator
choices.A: Add more redundancy to the power cabling
Since Joe is concerned about time, suggest calling back later when Joe has more time to troubleshoot
choices.C: Ask more open-ended questions to see if the issue can be narrowed down in order to properly identify the issue and save time
choices.B: Record the call and send it to the local intranet for future technicians to learn how to deal with calls like this one
choices.D: Inform the customer that there is a troubleshooting script that must be followed to get the issue resolved

comments.content: Yeah, I was def. expecting escalate the call to another tier to be one of the possible answers.

discussion.content:
Sometimes, to catch your fish, a wider net must be cast. Any test takers who have worked a customer service job can relate to this question.
Asking more open-ended questions to narrow down the issue is the most correct answer. If the technician had been pursuing a specific troubleshooting path up to this point, they may have been isolating the wrong issue. Specific queries can be made after broader ones have narrowed the issue down.
Directing a contact to call back later is inappropriate. Service calls should be dealt with at the first contact. Repeat callers indicate that an issue was not handled properly.
Recording the call is an incorrect answer because this does not bring the contact closer to resolution.
Informing the contact of a script, if any, is inappropriate. This dehumanizes the contact and may lead to a poor user review or needless supervisor escalation, and is bad customer relations in general.
This is the dumbest cert I have ever taken. What a complete joke.
D is the correct answer.

comments.content: Can't believe the moderator allowed this kind of answer

questions.question_text:
Joe, a customer, has informed a Tier 2 help desk technician that a computer will not boot up. After about ten minutes of troubleshooting, Joe is increasingly concerned and claims that the technician is wasting his time because he has already tried everything that has been suggested.
Which of the following should the technician do?
